channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Iraqi Militants Release 32 Turkish Truck Drivers
item.description: The drivers, who had been held for nearly a month, were handed over to security forces at the United Nations’ Mahmur camp in the Kurdish region of Iraq, Turkish officials said.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Presidents of China and South Korea Reaffirm Push for North Korean Denuclearization
item.description: A joint statement during President Xi Jinping's state visit to Seoul smoothed over differences that had prevented a more aggressive approach toward Pyongyang.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: U.S. Embassy in Uganda Warns of ‘Specific Threat’ to Airport
item.description: The alarm was one of several in East Africa where governments have sought to counter Al Shabab, a militant group based in Somalia.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Security officials patrolled Kampala on Thursday after the United States Embassy in Uganda warned of a threat to Entebbe International Airport.

item.title: Israel Mobilizing Forces Around Gaza
item.description: Amid tensions over the killings of four teenagers, Palestinian militants fired rockets into southern Israel, hitting three houses, and Israel carried out airstrikes against targets in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN and ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: A Palestinian man looked at the damage caused by an Israeli air strike on Thursday in Gaza City.

item.title: Opinion: North Korea’s Fear of Hollywood
item.description: Why does a dictator with nukes freak out about a James Franco sendup? Because he's into movies. Really.
item.dc:creator: By PAUL FISCHER

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Poland’s Culture War Rages On
item.description: The staging of a somewhat innocuous play has resulted in an unlikely defeat for the church.
item.dc:creator: By SLAWOMIR SIERAKOWSKI

item.title: A Rogue State Along Two Rivers
item.description: The victories gained by the militant group calling itself the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria were built on months of maneuvering along the Tigris and Euphrates Rivers, which define a region known as the cradle of civilization.
item.dc:creator: By JEREMY ASHKENAS, ARCHIE TSE, DEREK WATKINS and KAREN YOURISH

item.title: Lens Blog: Portraits on the Street, in the Moment
item.description: Jacques Sonck has spent almost 40 years in Belgium making portraits of people — with odd or singular looks — who capture his attention on the street.
item.dc:creator: By RENA SILVERMAN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Scorn for ‘Tiger Xu,’ From Official and Unofficial Sources
item.description: Chinese state-run newspapers and social media users alike are expressing contempt for Xu Caihou, a retired senior general expelled from the Communist Party over corruption allegations.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: The retired general Xu Caihou, seen here at a 2004 event, was expelled from the Communist Party this week.

item.title: China Takes Step Toward Freeing Currency from State Control
item.description: Beijing has let banks set their own exchange rates for the renminbi in over-the-counter transactions.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Lens Blog: An Alternative World Cup
item.description: While many soccer fans’ eyes were on Brazil, a group of would-be nation-states met in Sweden last month in the Conifa World Cup, a tournament for teams not recognized by the sport’s governing body.
item.category: The New York Times Lens Blog
item.dc:creator: By JAMES MONTAGUE
item.media:description: Kurdish players showed team pride in Ostersund.

item.title: Flights to U.S. Face Scrutiny After Threats Are Reported
item.description: The Department of Homeland Security said it would increase screening of passengers and cargo on United States-bound flights in response to threats from Al Qaeda’s affiliate in Yemen.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: As Deadline Nears for an Iran Nuclear Pact, the Fingers Are Pointing
item.description: With less than three weeks until a deadline for an agreement on Iran’s nuclear future, public sparring rests on the larger narrative of whether Iran should settle its estrangement from the West.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Bits Blog: After Uproar, European Regulators Question Facebook on Psychological Testing
item.description: The social network is facing potential investigations in Europe on whether it broke local privacy laws by manipulating the emotional content of users’ posts without their consent.
item.dc:creator: By VINDU GOEL
item.media:description: Facebook said last week that it deliberately manipulated the emotional content of posts in the news feeds of nearly 700,000 users to see if emotions were contagious.

item.title: Arab Boy’s Death Escalates Clash Over Abductions
item.description: In what may have been a retaliation for the kidnapping and killing of three Israeli teenagers who were buried a day earlier, a Palestinian youth was forced into a car and killed.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Suha Abu Khdeir, center, whose son Muhammad was found dead, with relatives on Wednesday. “We don’t feel safe,” she said.

item.title: Cheney’s Back, Blitzing Rivals and Drawing Scorn
item.description: Former Vice President Dick Cheney seems reinvigorated as he takes on President Obama, the Clintons, radical Islam, Rand Paul, his own party and history. But to many, he is a punch line.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER
item.media:description: Irritated by what he considers President Obama’s weakness, former Vice President Dick Cheney has formed an organization to promote American national security.

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: The Vatican: Exorcists’ Group Is Formally Recognized
item.description: The Vatican has formally recognized the International Association of Exorcists, a group of 250 priests in 30 countries who say they liberate the faithful from demons.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Tunisia: Four Soldiers Are Killed in Operation Against Militants
item.description: The Tunisian soldiers were killed by a land mine during an operation against Islamist militants in the north of the country, the state news agency TAP reported.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Government of Ecuador Can Sue Fugitive Bankers in U.S.
item.description: Ecuador has the right to sue a pair of fugitive bankers in courts in the United States to recover millions of dollars that the men are accused of embezzling, a Florida appellate court has ruled.
item.dc:creator: By FRANCES ROBLES

item.title: Iraqi Premier Places Unity Second to Fighting ISIS
item.description: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki said defeating extremist Sunni groups was more urgent than bridging Iraq’s political divides, contrary to the urging of the United States and others.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq, center, with lawmakers on Tuesday.

item.title: Russia Demands New Cease-Fire in Ukraine as Foreign Ministers Seek Path to Peace
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin condemned the renewed military effort, saying that he would move aggressively to protect the interests of Russians abroad.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: A pro-Russian fighter patrolled on Wednesday near Luhansk, eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Pakistan Approves Sweeping Antiterror Bill, Prompting Warnings From Rights Groups
item.description: The act allows security forces to shoot suspects on sight, arrest suspects without warrant and withhold information about where detainees are being held or what they are being charged with.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By SABA IMTIAZ and SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Business Briefing: China Relaxes Controls Over Exchange Rates
item.description: China said it would permit banks to set their own exchange rates for the renminbi against the dollar in deals with clients, in a step to relax controls to make the currency more market-driven.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: With Wild Stocks of Shrimp Dwindling, Tank Farming Is on the Rise
item.description: Shrimp farmers are trying to meet the growing demand for their product, but in an environmentally responsible way.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI
item.media:description: As wild-caught shrimp grow more scarce, tank-farming is expanding.

item.title: Open Source: Israel’s Justice Minister Condemns ‘Incitement’ on Facebook
item.description: The minister, Tzipi Livni, was considering action against soldiers who took part in a campaign calling for “revenge” on the Palestinian community for three boys’ deaths.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: A screen shot of an image on a Facebook page showed a man in an army uniform with the words, "The people of Israel demand revenge" written on his chest.
